newsitem.title: UK: UK Labour highlights Conservative split on Europe.
newsitem.headline: UK Labour highlights Conservative split on Europe.

text.p: The British Labour Party's foreign affairs spokesman, Robin Cook, highlighted on Friday what he called an open split in the ruling Conservative Party over economic and monetary union (EMU) and ties with the European Union.

Brandishing what he said was the personal manifesto of Agriculture Minister Angela Browning for the May 1 election, Cook told a news conference: "Angela Browning has invented her own policy on the (European) single currency."
Cook quoted Browning as saying: "This (EMU) is the end of sovereignity of the nation state and if that is what is offered I have made it very clear that I will not support it."
Cook said Prime Minister John Major must tell Browning to withdraw her manifesto or dismiss her from the government.
"For the Tory central office to pretend that this pledge is in line with government policy is to pile a flat lie on top of an open split."
Cook also highlighted what he said he was the rejection of the single European currency by Conservative MPs Graham Riddick, Olga Maitland and David Evans.
